headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Yankees 9, Tigers 5
summary: Mark Teixeira, Robinson Cano and Curtis Granderson all homered, and the Yankees' bullpen allowed just one run in four innings in a 9-5 win Wednesday over the Detroit Tigers.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Aug. 19, 2010

headline: China's Investing Turns to Neighbors
summary: China is looking more to its Asian neighbors' currencies and debt markets in its bid to lessen its reliance on the dollar.

headline: Dow, Up 0.1%, Clings to Retailer-Driven Rally
summary: U.S. stocks reversed early losses, led by retailers, but major energy stocks slid after oil inventories unexpectedly rose. The Dow ended up 9.16 points, or 0.1%, at 10415.01.

headline: N.M. Ranch, Breuer Home, Wash. Villa
summary: In this week's column: Media mogul John Malone buys a 290,100-acre ranch near Santa Fe. A modern home designed by Marcel Breuer hits the market in Litchfield, Conn. And interior designer Thomas Pheasant cuts the price on his home in Washington, D.C. Tour the homes.

headline: Cheap Week: 'Bad Luck' Bronx Studio
summary: Cheap Week ends with this co-op in the Bronx, priced to move at $59,900. The studio has hardwood floors, an improved kitchen and a vintage bathroom with pink and black tiles.

headline: Blotter
summary: A roundup of area police news.

headline: Pakistan Air Crash Blamed on Errors
summary: Safety experts believes that poor visibility and pilot navigation slipups likely caused last month's crash of a Pakistani airliner that killed 152 people on approach to Islamabad.

headline: Photos of the Day: Aug. 19
summary: In today's pictures, Afghan children play on Independence Day, fish wash ashore in the Philippines, storms shift the ground in Tennessee and more.

headline: New Securities Issues
summary: The following were among recent offerings and pricings in U.S. and non-U.S. capital markets, with terms and syndicate manager, based on information provided by Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva.

headline: GM Hires Marketing Executive From Hyundai
summary: General Motors Co. has tapped Christopher J. Perry to oversee the marketing of the car maker's Chevrolet brand, hiring him away from Hyundai Motor America Inc.

headline: Healthy Wraps for the Montauk Crowds
summary: Unlike typical beach shacks that serve chicken fingers and sugary iced tea, Joni's in Montauk puts an emphasis on organic and healthy options.

headline: FDA Panel Backs Cymbalta for Chronic Pain
summary: An FDA advisory panel narrowly backed an effort by Lilly to expand use of its antidepressant Cymbalta as a treatment for chronic pain.

headline: Dow Tumbles 1.4% on Reignited Recession Worry
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down 144.48 points, or 1.4%, to 10271.06, snapping a two-day winning streak. Most of the major benchmark indexes are now in the red for the week, month and year.

headline: Program Trading
summary: Program trading in the week ended Aug. 13 amounted to 27.4% of New York Stock Exchange average daily volume of 1.97 billion shares, or 540.1 million program shares traded per day.

headline: Top Democrat Criticizes Spill Report
summary: A top Democrat criticized the Obama administration's handling of a report that three-fourths of the oil spilled from BP's Gulf well had been cleaned up or broken down, after a government scientist said the report was rushed out and had not been subjected to a full scientific review.

headline: iShares MSCI Brazil, iShares Barclays 20+ Year Treas Bond: Money Flow Leaders (EWZ, TLT)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Dollar Advances as Data Spur Move to Safety
summary: The dollar advanced broadly, as deepening fears about the country's slow pace of recovery sent investors to the usual safe harbors.

headline: Gold at 7-Week High
summary: Gold futures hit a seven-week high after a flurry of disappointing economic data rejuvenated investors' recent flight to safety.

headline: Miner's Key Nomination
summary: Russia's Uralkali nominated Alexander Voloshin, a former chief of staff to Vladimir Putin, to its board of directors, a move likely to raise the potash producer's profile.

headline: Crude Settles Lower
summary: Crude-oil futures prices settled at a six-week low, stung by a rash of disappointing U.S. economic data and surging inventories.

headline: Shares of Security Software Makers Rise
summary: Shares of computer-security software makers rose following Intel's takeover offer for McAfee, with investors resetting values for the various companies and looking for the next big deal.

headline: Joys and Pains of a Global Paradigm Shift
summary: In a high-tech, globalized economy in which economic power is shifting from high-wage, advanced countries to low-wage developing  countries, it's perfectly reasonable for companies in some sectors to see big  growth opportunities while others are so squeezed that they're laying off  workers.

headline: Caterpillar's Sales Roll Along
summary: Caterpillar's retail sales continued their momentum, rising 32% in the three-month period ended in July, as demand for construction machinery in North America and Latin American picked up.

headline: European Markets Tumble
summary: European stocks sank and confidence slipped following worse-than-expected U.S. economic data, which offset earlier positive sentiment regarding mergers-and-acquisition news.

headline: BHP, Saskatchewan and Beijing
summary: None

headline: Merkel 1, Obama 0
summary: The Chancellor followed a simple economic rule: Do no harm—or at least not too much.

headline: RIM Shops for Mobile Ad Network
summary: Under pressure in the increasingly competitive wireless market, BlackBerry maker Research in Motion is shopping for a mobile advertising network.

headline: Unilever Deal Scrutinized
summary: The European Union's executive arm raised concerns about Unilever's proposed $1.65 billion acquisition of Sara Lee's personal-care unit.

headline: Yingli Green Posts Profit
summary: Yingli recovered from a prior-year loss in the second quarter caused by derivatives impacts as the Chinese solar-products maker saw demand rebound sharply.

headline: Small Business Casts Hopeful Eye on Lending Bill
summary: Small-business legislation pending in the Senate would aid some profitable firms with tax breaks, but opinions are mixed on the extent to which it would help get credit flowing again.

headline: Toro's Profit Rises 69%
summary: Toro reported 69% profit growth as demand for its landscaping and irrigation equipment continued to rebound.

headline: Transocean, BP Tussle Over Spill Data
summary: Transocean accused BP of withholding valuable information about the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, saying the oil giant is hurting Transocean's ability to conduct its own investigation. BP denies the accusations.

headline: Bull Leaps From Ring, Injuring 40
summary: A bull leapt into the packed grandstands of a Spanish bullring and ran amok, charging and trampling spectators and leaving 40 people injured, regional officials said Thursday.

headline: Sears Loss Narrows
summary: Sears said its loss narrowed by more than half following prior-year charges and as the retailer cut costs.

headline: Words From Golf's Ancient Twitterer
summary: Legendary golf writer Dan Jenkins discusses the 206 majors he's covered, Tiger Woods's future and more.

headline: Basel Panel Pursues Capital Rules to Limit Taxpayer Losses
summary: Financial instruments issued by banks to raise capital in order to satisfy regulatory requirements must include terms allowing regulators to convert them to equity or write them off in the event of the bank's failure, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision proposed.

headline: Staples Profit Rises 40%
summary: Staples's earnings rose 40% as the office-products retailer benefited from stronger margins and lower restructuring-related expenses.

headline: Infosys Plans New Social Media Policy for Staff
summary: Infosys plans to roll out a new social media policy for its employees, after staff complained in Internet chatrooms about the company's policies.

headline: U.K. Economy Starts Quarter Strongly
summary: The U.K. economy kicked off the third quarter with strong retail sales growth, weaker-than-expected government borrowing, firm industrial orders and a modest pickup in mortgage lending.

headline: EU: Greece Ready for Aid Tranche
summary: Greece's strong action to reduce its excessive budget deficit should pave the way for the payment of a second tranche of $11.57 billion in euro-zone financial aid to the stricken country in September.

headline: U.K.'s Surprising Resilience
summary: The U.K. may yet defy the most gloomy predictions. As policy makers have been arguing around the world, investors may be too negative about the outlook, although undoubted obstacles remain.

headline: Tiger Airways Holders Pare Stakes
summary: Tiger Airways said some key shareholders sold about US$92.5 million shares in a private placement, sending its stock price lower and prompting Thai Airways to reanalyze a planned partnership.

headline: Is Contractor Legit?
summary: After a recent hailstorm caused roof damage, contractors have been swarming around a Buffalo homeowner. June Fletcher offers advice on how to screen out the scammers.

headline: Chairman of Apple Supplier Steps Down
summary: Singapore's JLJ Holdings, the parent of a supplier of components to Apple, said its executive chairman has voluntarily stepped down.

headline: Williams-Sonoma Net Surges
summary: Williams-Sonoma's profit surged, hitting a record for the period, as revenue climbed amid a same-store sales recovery across its brands.

headline: CBO Puts 2010 Deficit at $1.34 Trillion
summary: A new projection from the Congressional Budget Office reflects a worsening of the deficit picture for fiscal 2011, but little change in other years since its last estimate in January.

headline: U.K. Names Trade Adviser
summary: Leon Brittan, former EU trade commissioner, has been appointed as a trade adviser to the U.K.'s coalition government.

headline: GameStop's Profit, Sales Edge Up
summary: Gamestop reported a 4.3% rise in profit on slightly higher sales, but the videogame seller lowered its earnings outlook.

headline: Cheap Week: Brooklyn Bargain
summary: This week, we're featuring some of the cheapest listings in the five boroughs. First is this 580-square-foot studio in Brooklyn near Ditmas Park, priced at $85,000.

headline: Sarkozy Faces Pressure on Growth
summary: Pressure is building on French President Sarkozy ahead of a meeting with his top ministers to confront the thorny question of unrealistic growth forecasts.

headline: Japan Rises on Stimulus Hopes
summary: Japanese shares fronted a rally across Asia as expectations of further monetary easing measures bolstered stocks. The Nikkei index rose 1.3%.

headline: China Allows Ringgit to Trade Against Yuan
summary: China for the first time allowed the yuan to trade against the Malaysian ringgit on the domestic market , the latest move in an effort to turn the yuan into a major global currency.

headline: Bundesbank Lifts Forecast
summary: Germany's central bank raised its forecast for economic growth in 2010, becoming the first official body to upgrade its outlook after data showed the fastest growth in 20 years.

headline: Japan Yields Hit New 7-Year Lows
summary: Japanese government bond yields marked fresh multi-year lows Thursday, as investors took the view that any fresh moves by the Bank of Japan would be unlikely to stem the yen's rise.

headline: Dollar Tree Profit Jumps 37%
summary: Dollar Tree's earnings jumped 37% as new stores contributed to revenue and same-store sales continued to improve.

headline: Avantha Power to Open IPO on Oct 11
summary: Avantha Power & Infrastructure plans to open its 12.50 billion rupees ($269 million) initial public offering on Oct. 11, joining the ranks of other power companies that have turned to the capital markets to help fund growth and meet demand for electricity in India.

headline: India Food Prices Steady
summary: Food prices in India remained little changed in the week to Aug. 7, reflecting market expectations that they would be stable, or ease only slightly, until an expected healthy summer-crop harvest boosts supplies around October.

headline: Tech Mahindra: Decision Making Still Slow in Telecom
summary: Clients of Indian software company Tech Mahindra are still putting off spending decisions as they wait for the global telecommunications industry to recover from the economic slowdown, Chief Financial Officer Sonjoy Anand said.

headline: Ringgit Surges to Near 13-Year High
summary: The Malaysian ringgit surged to a near 13-year high after the central bank allowed companies to use the currency to settle international trade.

headline: Daniel Schwammenthal: Mr. Westerwelle and Saudi Homophobia
summary: Germany's openly gay foreign minister outs himself as an appeaser.

headline: Immigration Impacts Australia Vote
summary: Immigration policy has emerged as a key theme in the closely fought Australian election campaign, particularly in big cities like Sydney, where new migrants often first settle and where pollsters say the vote will be won or lost.

headline: Thai Minister Urges Baht Action
summary: Thailand's commerce minister urged the central bank to do more to stabilize the baht, blaming the currency's strength for a sharp slowdown in export growth.

headline: Holcim's Net Profit Falls 12%
summary: Holcim joined rivals in warning that weak cement demand in Europe is offsetting steady growth in Asia as the company posted a 12% drop in quarterly net profit.

headline: Zimbabwe's Post-Cup Hangover
summary: Zimbabwe's officials had hoped that World Cup enthusiasm in host South Africa would spill across the borders and help revive a moribund domestic league—and perhaps boost an ailing economy and lift national spirits. It wasn't meant to be.

headline: The Chinese Military Challenge
summary: The PLA is seeking to push U.S. forces out of Asian waters.

headline: NDTV: In Talks for Alliance in Lifestyle Business
summary: Indian media company New Delhi Television said it is in talks for a "strategic alliance" for its lifestyle business.

headline: Benn Steil and Paul Swartz: Bye-Bye to the Fed-Funds Rate
summary: Ben Bernanke's 'exit strategy' will involve a sea change in the conduct of monetary policy. Just ask the European Central Bank.

headline: Keep an Eye on the Bouncing Jobless Claims
summary: The Labor Department's weekly tally of new claims for unemployment benefits has a remarkable track record of foreshadowing economic turning points.

headline: Talks Resume on Internet Traffic
summary: Broadband and telecommunications lobbyists restarted talks to develop a proposal for how Internet traffic should be managed. The FCC wasn't involved in the negotiations.

headline: Lewis to Join 'Quartet' for a Night
summary: Rock legend Jerry Lee Lewis will join the cast of "Million Dollar Quartet" on Sept. 10 at the Nederlander Theater.

headline: More Rappers Go Hollywood
summary: More than 350 fans stampeded the 23-year-old Bow Wow at Foot Locker in Herald Square where he was dressed in a Foot Locker uniform and Miami Heat cap to promote his film "Lottery Ticket."

headline: LG Readies Tablet, Optimus Smartphones
summary: LG Electronics plans to launch 10 more smartphones and its first tablet computer by the end of the year, as it scrambles to catch up with rivals.

headline: Small Firms Lagging, With Bulk of Job Losses
summary: Most of the job losses at the end of last year were concentrated in the smallest firms, underscoring how small businesses are lagging in the economic recovery.

headline: Strassel: New York's GOP Never Learns
summary: The controversy over Chris Cox's candidacy could cost the GOP N.Y.'s first congressional district.

headline: At QB, the Giants Have Bruises, Bandages and Bomar
summary: With starter Eli Manning and backup Jim Sorgi injured, coach Tom Coughlin turns to No. 3 quarterback Rhett Bomar.

headline: Dog Day At 'Mao' Premiere
summary: Monday was extra special for Australian director Bruce Beresford. It was his 70th birthday and he was also premiering his newest film, "Mao's Last Dancer." Jane Fonda showed up with her dog.

headline: Low-End Homes in 5 Boroughs
summary: A survey of bargain-basement listings show that purchase prices are much lower than their highs 1½ years ago.

headline: Humble Potash Gleams
summary: Potash, a mineral with a long history in agriculture, is playing a bigger role as population growth drives demand for feed crops.

headline: Mexico Under Siege
summary: Drug violence in Mexico's business capital and richest city has prompted an outcry from business leaders who have asked President Calderón to send in more soldiers to stem the violence.

headline: A Set Fit for Shakespeare
summary: At a Hamptons mansion, "All's Well That Ends Well."

headline: Russell 2000 Gains for Third Day in Row
summary: Small-capitalization stocks modestly rose for a third day in a row as strength in the consumer sectors fueled Wednesday's gains.

headline: Prized Murals Draw New Interest
summary: Mexican artist Miguel Covarrubias painted six colorful maps portraying Pacific Rim life for the 1939-1940 World's Fair. Now the rarely seen murals are the subject of behind-the-scenes jockeying by several San Francisco institutions.

headline: R. Eden Martin: Unfunded Public Pensions—the Next Quagmire
summary: A federal bailout would cost trillions and prevent necessary reforms. But there are several ways states can rationalize their workers' retirement benefits.

headline: The Symphony You Can Take With You
summary: New York composer Tristan Perich wrote a five-movement piece of music in programming code and loaded it onto a $1.50 chip. The result goes on sale next week.

headline: U.S. Prods China on Pakistan
summary: The U.S. has increased its aid commitment to flood-ravaged Pakistan to $150 million from $90 million and Richard Holbrooke, the U.S. special envoy to Pakistan and Afghanistan, called on China to do more.

headline: Oil-Cleanup Estimates Draw Fire
summary: The Obama administration's conclusion that much of the oil released into the Gulf of Mexico from the Deepwater Horizon spill has disappeared is coming under additional fire from scientists.

headline: As Web Surfers Share, Marketers Track
summary: Those ubiquitous "AddThis" buttons, used to share Web material, raise  eyebrows for the consumer data they collect in the process.

headline: Hedge Funds Tap ETF for Gold Bets
summary: Hedge funds managed by high-profile investors show they are using SPDR Gold Shares, an ETF, to buy gold, even as the ETF's growing clout may be chipping at gold's role as an asset that moves to its own beat.

headline: Fixes That Make Any Room Pop
summary: A room, says television production designer Mark Worthington, "should show the history of how you've developed the space, with individual pieces from different moments of your life."

headline: Rangel Faces Changing District
summary: With a critical primary vote scheduled before a verdict in Rep. Charles Rangel congressional ethics trial, judgment of the Harlem Democrat will come first from the voters. Their verdict will rest on old rivalries, shifting demographics, and new alliances.

headline: A Wholistic Focus on Problem-Solving
summary: Whole Earth Catalog founder Stewart Brand talks about the promise of cities for solving problems.

headline: Swiss Life's First-Half Profit Soars
summary: Insurer Swiss Life Holding reported an 89% increase in first-half net profit but cautioned that stubbornly low interest rates render the outlook challenging.

headline: Pennsylvania Restoration
summary: Designed by Frank Weise, this mid-century modern home was marketed as a teardown when the current owner bought it a few years ago. He carefully restored it.

headline: Lunchtime Spot for the Tech Set
summary: Cafe Borrone in Menlo Park offers diners the chance to people-watch everyone from tech financiers to start-up entrepreneurs.

headline: Artists and Monsters on Screen
summary: A screening of "On the Waterfront" at the very docks where it was shot and a documentary about the Nazi propaganda machine lead this week's repertory film highlights.

headline: Freeing the Yuan
summary: A welcome step to internationalize China's currency.

headline: For Those Who Have It All...
summary: At the New York International Gift Fair this week, there was everything from a fluorescent-green door stop in the shape of a roller skate to frog slippers that Snooki has been spotted wearing.

headline: H1-B Visas Are OnlyFor Non-U.S. Skills
summary: After reading your editorial "No Bad Idea Left Behind" (Aug. 12), I have one question: Which side are you on? What good does it make to create jobs in the U.S. if they are going to be filled by foreigners?

headline: Facebook Plays Location Game
summary: Facebook's new location game Places lets members "check in" to establishments. Walt Mossberg found the service easy to use.

headline: Green Light on Barclays Pact
summary: A judge approved a $298 million settlement that allows Barclays to avoid prosecution over dealings with sanctioned countries.

headline: Target Gains 2.5%; Exxon, Chevron Fall
summary: Retailers led stocks slightly higher as better-than-expected earnings from Target lifted Kohl's and J.C. Penney. Energy concerns took a hit.

headline: He's a Throwback and a Survivor
summary: In his 17th NFL season, at age 38, fullback Tony Richardson of the Jets excels at a dying art.

headline: In Blagojevich Trial, Democrats Lost
summary: The only clear losers in the Blagojevich trial were Democrats, who face the prospect of another trial in the middle of a tough midterm-election season.

headline: Volvo Will Buff Its Brand
summary: Volvo Cars will have to upgrade its image to more clearly define its brand, said Stefan Jacoby, the Swedish auto maker's new CEO.

headline: J&J to Revamp Manufacturing
summary: J&J is reorganizing its manufacturing side and creating a new position reporting directly to the chief executive to ensure quality production across the company, Chief Executive William Weldon said.

headline: In Search of Justice for Wall (Street)
summary: David Weidner writes that legal settlements by Wall Street firms have often been weakly worded penalties, handed to judges for the rubber stamp. But judges are finally questioning this brand of pseudo justice.

headline: U.S. Plays Big Role in GM Share Offering
summary: The U.S. government, as GM's largest shareholder, will determine the timing, size and price of the auto maker's initial public offering.

headline: Target Profit Climbs 14%
summary: Target's earnings rose 14% as the company's credit-card business showed continued strength.

headline: Time for Antitrust to Bite the Dust
summary: It is discouraging to read that a counselor to the foremost victim of antitrust in our time has joined the chorus of antirust professionals, who are singing that antitrust is, or can be, "sound" ("The High-Tech World Still Needs Antitrust," Letters, Aug. 16).

headline: New Jersey's Muni-Bond Situation
summary: The Traveling Wilburys once crooned that, "In Jersey anything's legal as long as you don't get caught." The state may have taken that too literally.

headline: Majority Favor State Climate Policy
summary: A poll found that 57% of Californians think the state should set its own climate-change policy, a potential blow to proponents of Proposition 23, a ballot measure that would suspend California's landmark limits on greenhouse-gas emissions.

headline: Basel: Rules Won't Hurt Growth
summary: The global economy won't suffer if banks are forced to adopt tighter standards on capital and liquidity, the Financial Stability Board and Basel Committee said.

headline: Humiliation Comes in Two Flavors
summary: The two most-productive running backs in the NFL last season, Chris Johnson and Steven Jackson, are as different as humanly possible. But if you had to try to stop one of them, which one would you choose?

headline: Henninger: Privileges of the House
summary: Charlie Rangel's floor speech echoed the complaints of an earlier fallen House potentate, former Speaker Jim Wright.

headline: Bidder Tops Zell for Greenwich Site
summary: A little-known company called Greenwich Thames Realty trumped Sam Zell's Equity Residential as the winning bidder of a bankruptcy auction for a vacant land parcel in downtown Manhattan.

headline: Cameron Stracher: Slow and Steady Loses the Race
summary: U.S. runners are pokier than they were in 1979.

headline: Surf Avenue Turf War
summary: Memories of Coney Island as the "birthplace of the modern American amusement industry" are about to be erased.

headline: Rolls-Royce Resists Airbus's Engine Plan
summary: Airbus's proposal to put new engines on its fast-selling A320 jetliners faces resistance from its top engine supplier.

headline: SEC Sues New Jersey Over Bond Offerings
summary: New Jersey settled SEC charges that the state misled investors about the fiscal health of its two largest state pensions while issuing billions of dollars in bonds.

headline: Tip of the Day
summary: In the rolling hills of northwest England, York's Ebor meeting is the last big flat-racing festival of the British summer and the Darley Yorkshire Oaks could turn out to be the best race of the week.

headline: India May Double Individual Cap for IPOs
summary: India's capital-markets regulator proposed doubling the cap on retail investments in public issues for each individual in a move aimed at increasing the investor base and encouraging participation.

headline: Chinese Banks Post Profit Jumps
summary: Bank of Communications and China Merchants Bank posted strong first-half profit increases, a good sign for other state-run lenders reporting in the days ahead.

headline: Exxon Ends Ghana Plan
summary: Kosmos Energy called off the sale of its Ghana oil assets to Exxon Mobil, dealing a blow to the U.S. oil major's drive to tap a major new oil region in West Africa.

headline: Enterprise Dispatch
summary: A new robotic lawnmower can detect darting gophers, and a decline in business bankruptcies isn't necessarily good for small businesses.

headline: What Were the Mets Thinking?
summary: The Mets' handling of K-Rod and other major signings calls their judgment into question.

headline: After Potash Bid, Traders Hunt for Takeover Targets
summary: U.S. Steel options were active, as they have been previously, amid speculation of a possible bid by Arcelor Mittal. SunTrust Banks and Cliffs Natural Resources also saw a pickup in options action.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide for Aug. 19, 2010

headline: Egg Producers Struggle With New Rules
summary: Two years after California voters approved a law designed to create humane standards for farm animals, it isn't clear what egg producers need to do to comply with rules that take effect in 2015.

headline: Intel Bets Its Chips on McAfee
summary: Intel agreed to buy security-software specialist McAfee for $7.68 billion, a surprise transaction designed to jump-start the chip giant's uphill effort to move its technology beyond computers.

headline: Google vs. Facebook on Places
summary: The launch of Facebook's location service ratchets up the competition with Google Places, as both compete for local advertising.

headline: Cafe Borrone
summary: Less than a mile away from Stanford University and Sand Hill Road's venture-capital row, Cafe Borrone offers people-watchers a glimpse at everyone from tech financiers to start-up entrepreneurs.

headline: Blagojevich 23, Fitzgerald 1
summary: Chicago's jester politician humiliates the Justice Department.

headline: Hiring Rises in City of London
summary: The number of new jobs in London's financial-services sector rose in July as hiring conditions improved despite weak second-quarter bank earnings and concerns about a double-dip recession.

headline: Carmelo Knots Up His Own NBA Saga
summary: Just when you thought the summer was safe from yet another psychoanalysis of a restless NBA superstar, here comes the sticky saga of Carmelo Anthony's Big, Fat Denver-Bashing Wedding.

headline: Ron Adner and William Vincent: Get Ready for Ads in Books
summary: For those who think this too radical a notion, consider the overwhelming product placement in movies, music videos and video games.

headline: Gift From Helmsley's Trust Will Create Heart Center
summary: The trust that bears the name of the late Leona Helmsley will announce a $25 million grant to New York's Mount Sinai Medical Center to create the Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust Cardiovascular Translational Research Center.

headline: The Lockerbie Bomber and Scotland's Disgrace
summary: Scottish Justice Minister Kenny MacAskill turned a mass-murderer into a hero.

headline: Motorola, Others Granted Net Funds
summary: Motorola Inc. was among several companies to win millions in government funding Wednesday as the Obama administration announced $1.8 billion in new broadband stimulus grants and loans.

headline: EMI Will Hold Talks With Citi Over Deal
summary: U.K. music company EMI remains in danger of defaulting on bank covenants despite several cash injections. Meanwhile, EMI and Citigroup plan talks to settle litigation over the buyout.
